Award.AwardTitle: CC*DNI Networking Infrastructure - University of Alabama SciNet

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
The University of Alabama (UA) is designing and deploying a science DMZ herein referred to as UA SciNet to support the rapid expansion in research across multiple science and engineering disciplines. UA SciNet is based on the design patterns and best practices emerging from Internet2 and ESNet. UA SciNet is a dedicated, isolated network connecting to the UA wide-area network at the campus network border. It provides 40 Gbps connections between active data-intensive science areas and high performance computing and research storage resources. It provides an initial 400% bandwidth increase for research and lays the foundation for 100 Gbps connectivity to the wide area network via the UA System Regional Optical network and Southern Crossroads services. It includes a robust performance monitoring and problem resolution component using perfSONAR. It also uses wide-area remote DMA (RDMA) to achieve high-bandwidth remote access to UA Big Data resources.

The research impacted by the project includes hydro-meteorologic modeling, disaster event prediction and mitigation, human behavior, and particle physics, specifically leveraging the data-intensive operations at the recently completed National Water Center on the UA campus. This project also works in coordination with other initiatives both on campus and at the regional and state levels to ensure its effective integration and to ensure its benefits are fully leveraged. Further, the project brings unique education and training opportunities to undergraduate and graduate students, researchers and system and network professionals to the areas of advanced network infrastructure, data-intensive science, and performance monitoring and diagnostics.

1. Intellectual Merits: It mainly includes the following 5 aspects: (1) We have designed and implemented a science network component at The University of Alabama; (2) The built science network has facilitated the data access and transport needs of data-intensive research activities at UA. (3) We have ensured that the science network is operationally stable, secure, and capable of delivering sustained performance at or better than 90% of the engineered bandwidth capacity. (4) We have investigated the perfSONAR configuration, implementation, and operational best practices and implemented them in the UA SciNet. (5) We have studied Remote Direct Memory Access (RDMA) data transfer capabilities across UA SciNet and to external collaborators. 

2. Broader Impacts: It mainly consists of the following 4 aspects: (1) A working and sustainable science DMZ has been established and is operational on the UA campus.  This capability has provided significant benefits across research disciplines and has established a foundation for enabling data-intensive research activities. Project participants have achieved improved understanding of the technologies involved and the skills required to implement a Science DMZ. (2) The UA SciNet science DMZ may be used by any research discipline on the campus.  The understanding gained and infrastructure deployed under this project, along with concurrent contributions from the University, have established a shared resource that will benefit multiple disciplines. (3) The project has enabled the segmentation of science/research related network traffic from general campus network traffic in an efficient and scalable way and has allowed alternative information security architectures to support the unique requirements of research data management. (4) The project has expanded and extended the UA information network capabilities to serve science and research activities for years to come.  It has opened the door for data-intensive research collaboration both on-campus and with external collaborators and facilities.
